title: Inflation and the Full Faith and Credit of the United States
sub_head: The issue isn’t whether the U.S. will repay its debt, but whether it can service the debt.
body:
John Cochrane is correct that our inflation is attributable to the excessive government spending in the wake of the pandemic (“The Fed Can’t Cure Inflation by Itself,” op-ed, June 28). He is wrong, however, in suggesting that the inflation reflects a loss of faith that the U.S. will repay its debt.
The issue isn’t whether the U.S. will repay its debt, but whether it can service the debt. The interest cost of the debt is currently about 1.5% of U.S. gross domestic product, which is half its postwar peak of 3% of GDP.
